supporting.text: Tiger sharks, like many other shark species, rely on ram ventilation to breathe, which requires continuous swimming to pass water over their gills.

attacks.text: Tiger sharks, like many other shark species, rely on ram ventilation to breathe, which requires continuous swimming to pass water over their gills.
Some tiger sharks have been observed resting on the ocean floor, suggesting they can temporarily stop swimming while still obtaining oxygen through buccal pumping.
Buccal pumping in tiger sharks is inefficient and only used in rare circumstances, making continuous swimming the primary and nearly constant mode of respiration.
Captive tiger sharks in aquariums have adapted to stationary life, proving they can survive without continuous swimming.
Captive environments are artificial and do not reflect natural behavior; wild tiger sharks depend on ram ventilation for survival.

supporting.text: Scientific studies have documented tiger sharks resting on the ocean floor, indicating they can stop swimming temporarily.

attacks.text: Scientific studies have documented tiger sharks resting on the ocean floor, indicating they can stop swimming temporarily.
The observed resting behavior may be an exception rather than the norm, as most tiger sharks are constantly swimming to breathe.
Even if resting is rare, the documented cases prove that tiger sharks are physiologically capable of stopping, contradicting the absolute claim.
The resting behavior might be stress-induced or pathological, not representative of healthy tiger shark behavior.

supporting.text: Unlike obligate ram ventilators, tiger sharks possess spiracles that allow them to pump water over their gills while stationary.

attacks.text: Unlike obligate ram ventilators, tiger sharks possess spiracles that allow them to pump water over their gills while stationary.
Spiracles in tiger sharks are less efficient than ram ventilation, making prolonged stationary periods energetically costly.
Tiger sharks rarely use spiracles in the wild, as they are adapted to continuous swimming for hunting and oxygen uptake.
Spiracles may not function effectively in adult tiger sharks, as they are more developed in juveniles.
Studies show adult tiger sharks still actively use spiracles in low-oxygen environments.

supporting.text: Observations of tiger sharks in captivity show they can remain motionless for extended periods without respiratory distress.

attacks.text: Observations of tiger sharks in captivity show they can remain motionless for extended periods without respiratory distress.
Captive environments often lack natural stressors and currents, which may reduce the need for constant swimming compared to wild conditions.
Studies on wild tiger sharks show they frequently rest in shallow, low-current areas, supporting the idea that they can stop swimming in certain environments.
Some shark species exhibit buccal pumping (actively moving water over gills while stationary), but tiger sharks primarily rely on ram ventilation (requiring forward motion).
Recent observations document tiger sharks using buccal pumping in captivity, suggesting behavioral flexibility in respiration methods.

supporting.text: Tiger sharks exhibit buccal pumping, a mechanism that enables them to breathe without constant forward movement.

attacks.text: Tiger sharks exhibit buccal pumping, a mechanism that enables them to breathe without constant forward movement.
Buccal pumping in tiger sharks is less efficient than ram ventilation, requiring them to still swim most of the time to meet oxygen demands.
Studies show tiger sharks can sustain sufficient oxygen levels via buccal pumping alone during rest periods in shallow waters.
Shallow-water rest periods are rare for tiger sharks due to predation risks and foraging needs, making buccal pumping insufficient for long-term survival.
